results.title: Electra, my love [DVD]
results.brief_description: Hungarian director Miklos Jancso has created a stunning allegorical work about the perils of political deception and the power of vengeance. Having vowed revenge for the murder of her father fifteen years earlier, Electra awaits the return of her exiled brother, who she hopes will exact justice on her oppressors. Jansco relocates the classic Greek myth “Electra” (by Sophocles, written 410 B.C.E) to the arid plains of Hungary, where using a cast of thousands, he creates a symbolic work of extreme power and beauty. Using dance, song and movement Jansco conveys the themes of familial loyalty, tyranny and treachery in a series of long takes (about twelve in all) whereupon his camera roams the events unfurling, presenting an artful and ambitious work. The medieval tone (the film is replete with horses, knives, swords, flowing dresses and a lot of nudity) underscores the filmmaker’s desires to convey mythological poeticism, drawing on the folkloric nature of the source text. The film was also interpreted as an analogy for the state of politics in Hungary at the time, when political leaders were feeding the people a complex web of political lies and deceptions, enslaving them with empty promises of a socialist state. Cast includes Mari Torocsik, Jozsef Madaras, Gyorgy Cserhalmi and Lajos Balazsovits.

results.title: Electra tries to speak
results.brief_description: A modern interpretation of the classic Greek tragedy ‘Electra’ showing how hard it is to deliver a clear determined statement.

results.title: El Pueblo
results.brief_description: Depicts life in the small community of Villaleunga del Rosario, set high in the mountains of Andalucia in Spain. The village is sustained by the farms which surround it and a modest workshop manufacturing leather goods. The farms are small, often arid and far from the village itself, providing a meagre living from cattle, sheep and goats. But the sense of community is strong, the people’s enduring allegiance and identity being with the village in which they live.

results.title: Eisenhower
results.brief_description: A biography of former President Eisenhower covering his experiences during World War II, his presidency at Columbia University, the formation of NATO, his visit to Korea and his years in the White House.

results.title: Eight parts of a business letter
results.creator_credit: William Lewin, G Russell Taylor and Library Films
results.brief_description: Shows how mail is handled, why letters are standardised as to form in business, difference between social and business forms, heading, introductory address, salutation, complimentary close, signature, outside address, return address, proper folding and enclosing of business letters, two-page letters, window envelope, basic display and arrangement.

results.title: Eight or nine in the morning
results.creator_credit: Felix Greene and Felix Greene Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “One Mans China”.
An insight into China’s new educational ideas - old traditions have been abandoned, and education today is non-competitive, with exams rarely given. Looks at the status of intellectuals and touches on background philosophy since the revolution. Suitable for secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The People's communes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Felix Greene and Felix Greene Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “One Mans China”.
Uses scenes from three communes in different parts of China to show the range of work and activities carried on in communes. However, a clear picture of people’s rules within these communes and the structural organisation is not shown.

results.title: The Great treasure house
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “One Mans China”.
Covers the theme of medicine in China. Shows traditional medicine, including acupuncture and herbalism. Since the Cultural Revolution many remarkable new applications for the ancient art of acupuncture have been discovered, and some of these are shown. We also see ‘barefoot doctors’, trained in simple medicine, working in minor illnesses in small villages. With the help of modern techniques being developed, alongside ancient and traditional medicine, the Chinese are among the healthiest people in the world today.
